Arg.V:
#!/bin/bash
function updatepk() { if [ ! -z $1 ]; then if [ -e /var/run/yum.pid ];then exit 10 fi result=`yum -y update $1 2>&1` status=$? commandexist=`echo $result | grep -E "yum: command not found"` if [ "$commandexist" != "" ]; then exit 8 fi
commandexist=`echo $result | grep -E "yum: No such file or directory"` if [ "$commandexist" != "" ]; then exit 8 fi
islock=`echo $result | grep -E "lock /var/run/yum.pid"`
if [ "$islock" != "" ]; then exit 10 fi
islock=`echo $result | grep -E "/var/run/yum.pid: another copy is running"`
if [ "$islock" != "" ]; then exit 10 fi
isnotconnected=`echo $result | grep -E "There was an error communicating with RHN"` if [ "$isnotconnected" != "" ]; then exit 9 fi
isnotconnected=`echo $result | grep -E "This system is not registered with RHN"` if [ "$isnotconnected" != "" ]; then exit 9 fi
isnotconnected=`echo $result | grep -E "No Repositories Available to Set Up"` if [ "$isnotconnected" != "" ]; then exit 9 fi isnotconnected=`echo $result | grep -E "Error Class Code: 9 Error Class Info: Invalid System Credentials"` if [ "$isnotconnected" != "" ]; then exit 9 fi isscriptletfailed=`echo $result | grep -E "error:" | grep -E "scriptlet failed, exit status 255"` if [ "$isscriptletfailed" != "" ]; then exit 6 fi if [ $status -ne 0 ];then exit 7 fi fi } updatepk nss
exit 0

Vulnerability.Title: nss bug fix and enhancement update
Vulnerability.Description: Network Security Services (NSS) is a set of libraries designed to support cross-platform development of security-enabled client and server applications. Notably, this update fixes the following bugs: Querying an LDAP over SSL (LDAPS) server previously failed when the "ssf=256" parameter defining the security strength factor (SSF) was used in the OpenLDAP configuration. The following error message was recorded in the /var/log/slapd.log file: slapd[2030]: conn=1001 op=0 RESULT tag=97 err=13 text=stronger confidentiality required NSS cipher order has been modified to prefer ciphers that use 256-bit keys over ciphers that use 128-bit bulk encryption ciphers. As a result, OpenLDAP configurations with "ssf=256" no longer cause the mentioned error. (BZ#1195766) Following a prior security update for Windows Server 2012 R2, multiple NSS-enabled applications, including ldapsearch and python-ldap, failed Transport Layer Security (TLS) negotiation on this system and did not work properly. This update modifies the signature algorithms sent as a part of the TLS 1.2 handshake so that the affected applications work as expected with Windows Server 2012 R2. (BZ#1212286) The RSA_WITH_NULL_SHA_256, RSA_WITH_NULL_SHA, and RSA_WITH_NULL_MD5 ciphers were previously missing from Red Hat Enterprise Linux 7 systems with the 3.18.0 or 3.19.1 version of the nss packages installed. Consequently, it was not possible to connect to servers using these ciphers. A patch has been applied to fix this problem, and the mentioned NULL ciphers can now be used as expected on Red Hat Enterprise Linux 7 systems. (BZ#1245627) In addition, this update adds the following enhancements: Applications using protocol versions that NSS enables by default now additionally support the TLS version 1.1 and TLS version 1.2 protocols. (BZ#1171318) Applications that use the default NSS cipher list now support connections to servers that use Elliptic Curve Digital Signature Algorithm (ECDSA) certificates. (BZ#1059670) Applications that use the default NSS cipher list now support connections to servers that require the Elliptic Curve Diffie-Hellman Ephemeral (ECDHE) key exchange. (BZ#1202494) Users of nss are advised to upgrade to these updated packages, which fix these bugs and add these enhancements. Note for remediation: Please disable the SELinux for RHEL 4/5 when repairing, or some rpm packages will fail to install.
